TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national currently resident in GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON , Director in ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) of GPE convicted the applicant of an aggravated narcotics offence and sentenced him to imprisonment .
On DATE ORG ( ulkomaalaisvirasto , utlänningsverket ) ordered the applicant to be deported to GPE .
The applicant started to serve his prison sentence on DATE in GPE .
On DATE ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) of GPE upheld the applicant ’s conviction and fixed his sentence at DATE and DATE . This judgment was final .
In a report dated DATE the Deputy Governor of ORG took a position on the applicant ’s placement , noting that he was due to be released on DATE .

On DATE ORG decided that the applicant should be transferred to GPE with a view to serving the rest of his sentence there . ORG relied on section CARDINAL , subsection LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on ORG operation in the Enforcement of Certain Criminal Sanctions , as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , as well as on LAW to the Convention on ORG ( NORP Treaty Series no . CARDINAL ; Finnish Treaty Series no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . The applicant ’s transfer was subject to the consent of ORG .

The applicant appealed to ORG ( hallinto - oikeus , förvaltningsdomstolen ) of GPE , arguing that enforcing the transfer order would violate Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL . Firstly , he risked being placed in the same prison as other members of the gang in whose activities he had been involved , CARDINAL of whom he had denounced during the criminal proceedings . Secondly , the general prison conditions in GPE were worse . Thirdly , the applicant argued that in GPE he would , as a first - time offender being of good behaviour in prison , be entitled to release on parole after having served CARDINAL of his sentence . In GPE release on parole would arise only when he had served CARDINAL of his sentence and even then on a more discretionary basis . By ordering that he should serve the rest of his sentence in GPE ORG effectively prolonged his sentence beyond that which he would have served , had he been allowed to remain in GPE . This was said to be in violation of LAW .
In its opinion to ORG stated the following ( as transcribed by the court ) :

“ ... ORG has been sentenced to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , of which he will , as a first - time offender , be serving DATE and DATE . According to ORG of the NORP ORG as well as its international unit , it would be possible for ORG to obtain a conditional release in GPE on having served CARDINAL of his sentence , that is to say DATE , DATE . [ His ] possibility of being released conditionally in GPE is therefore not significantly smaller than in GPE and the NORP legislation does not in this respect differ significantly from our own . According to the NORP authorities , the possibility for ORG to obtain a conditional release depends inter alia on factors which [ he ] himself may influence by his own deeds and behaviour . ... The conditions in which the sentence [ would be ] served in GPE [ would not ] differ significantly from those prevailing in GPE . The prohibition of retroactive criminal law does not apply to the case . ... ”

On DATE ORG refused the applicant ’s appeal , finding that , even though he was likely to serve a significantly longer prison sentence in GPE , this in itself did not constitute a violation of LAW . Nor were the general prison conditions in the receiving country such as to subject him to a risk of treatment proscribed by LAW . The risk that he might face on account of having denounced members of the drug gang had not been substantiated . In any event , there was no reason to believe that the NORP prison authorities would be unable to curb , to the extent possible , any such violence . Nor did ORG find that LAW would be violated as a result of any transfer to GPE as the sentence he would actually be serving there would not exceed the sentence imposed by the NORP courts .

On DATE the NORP ORG requested its NORP counterpart to consent to the applicant ’s transfer . On DATE the Minister of Justice of GPE gave consent for the transfer to GPE . The applicant disputed the consent of the Minister of ORG in ORG and requested the annulment of the consent . On DATE ORG suspended the proceedings of the administrative case until the application at hand was examined .

On DATE the Governor of the GPE prison decided to release the applicant conditionally on DATE . On DATE the applicant was immediately deported to GPE pursuant to the decision of ORG DATE . According to the information provided by the applicant ’s representative on DATE the applicant is currently at liberty in GPE .

Under LAW , LAW ) of LAW ( laki rangaistusten täytäntöönpanosta , lag om verkställighet av straff ) a person sentenced to imprisonment may be conditionally released where he or she has served CARDINAL or , exceptionally , CARDINAL of the sentence , in the latter case provided the prisoner has served no prison sentence during DATE preceding the offence .

Under LAW , subsection CARDINAL of the LAW the factors to be taken into account in the decision to release a prisoner conditionally include , inter alia , the nature of and the motives for the offence , the prisoner ’s earlier life style and his behaviour in the prison , as well as the situation the prisoner would face on release .

Pursuant to LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection PERCENT ) of the LAW a prisoner may appeal to a district court inter alia against the postponement of a conditional release on his or her having served CARDINAL of the sentence ( whichever is applicable under LAW , LAW ) .
In its report of DATE ( no . CARDINAL ) ORG noted the following ( on p. CARDINAL ) :

“ ... In DATE [ a conditional release ] was almost never postponed . Following the instruction issued by ORG in DATE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) postponements have been very rare and almost exclusively based on the prisoner ’s consent . ... ”
And further ( on p. CARDINAL ) :

“ [ The proposals now made ] would not change the existing legislation as regards the possibility of obtaining a conditional release on having served CARDINAL of a sentence . Nor would there be any change as regards those prisoners , who had served no prison term during DATE preceding their offence and who are [ therefore ] to be released on having served CARDINAL of their sentence . ... ”

The objectives of the Convention on ORG ( NORP Treaty Series no . CARDINAL ; Finnish Treaty Series no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; hereinafter “ the LAW ” ) , including its LAW no . CARDINAL ; Finnish Treaty Series no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , are to develop international co - operation in the field of criminal law and to further the ends of justice and the social rehabilitation of sentenced persons . According to the LAW , foreigners who are deprived of their liberty as a result of their commission of a criminal offence should be given the opportunity to serve their sentences within their own society .
ORG entered into force for GPE on CARDINAL DATE and LAW on DATE . GPE ratified LAW and LAW on DATE and DATE , respectively . They entered into force for GPE on DATE and DATE , respectively .

LAW enables the transfer of a sentenced person from “ the sentencing ORG ” to “ the administering State ” provided inter alia that the person in question is a national of the administering State ; that he or she ( or in some instances a legal representative ) consents to the transfer ; that the acts or omissions on account of which the sentence has been imposed constitute a criminal offence according to the law of the administering ORG or would constitute a criminal offence if committed on its territory ; and provided that the sentencing and administering GPE both agree to the transfer .
Article CARDINAL ( “ Effect of transfer for administering ORG ” ) reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . The competent authorities of the administering State shall :
( a ) NORP continue the enforcement of the sentence immediately or through a court or administrative order , under the conditions set out in LAW , or

( b ) convert the sentence , through a judicial or administrative procedure , into a decision of that ORG , thereby substituting for the sanction imposed in the sentencing ORG a sanction prescribed by the law of the administering ORG for the same offence , under the conditions set out in LAW .
CARDINAL . NORP The administering State , if requested , shall inform the sentencing State before the transfer of the sentenced person as to which of these procedures it will follow .
CARDINAL . The enforcement of the sentence shall be governed by the law of the administering ORG and that ORG alone shall be competent to take all appropriate decisions . ... ”
Article CARDINAL ( “ Continued enforcement ” ) provides the following :
“ CARDINAL . In the case of continued enforcement , the administering State shall be bound by the legal nature and duration of the sentence as determined by the sentencing ORG .

ORG . If , however , this sentence is by its nature or duration incompatible with the law of the administering ORG , or its law so requires , that ORG may , by a court or administrative order , adapt the sanction to the punishment or measure prescribed by its own law for a similar offence . As to its nature , the punishment or measure shall , as far as possible , correspond with that imposed by the sentence to be enforced . It shall not aggravate , by its nature or duration , the sanction imposed in the sentencing ORG , nor exceed the maximum prescribed by the law of the administering ORG . ”
LAW Conversion of sentence ” ) reads as follows :
“ CARDINAL . In the case of conversion of sentence , the procedures provided for by the law of the administering ORG apply . When converting the sentence , the competent authority :
( a ) shall be bound by the findings as to the facts insofar as they appear explicitly or implicitly from the judgment imposed in the sentencing ORG ;
( b ) may not convert a sanction involving deprivation of liberty to a pecuniary sanction ;
( c ) shall deduct the full period of deprivation of liberty served by the sentenced person ; and
( d ) shall not aggravate the penal position of the sentenced person , and shall not be bound by any minimum which the law of the administering ORG may provide for the offence or offences committed .

CARDINAL . If the conversion procedure takes place after the transfer of the sentenced person , the administering State shall keep that person in custody or otherwise ensure his presence in the administering ORG pending the outcome of that procedure . ”
LAW provides as follows :

“ Upon being requested by the sentencing ORG , the administering ORG may , subject to the provisions of this LAW , agree to the transfer of a sentenced person without the consent of that person , where the sentence passed on the latter , or an administrative decision consequential to that sentence , includes an expulsion or deportation order or any other measure as the result of which that person will no longer be allowed to remain in the territory of the sentencing ORG once he or she is released from prison . ”
At the time of the commission of the applicant ’s offence illegal possession of narcotics was punishable by DATE imprisonment pursuant to LAW , subsection CARDINAL of LAW of GPE .

The Penal Code replaced LAW on DATE . According to LAW criminal offences are divided into offences in the first degree and offences in the second degree . A criminal offence in the first degree are those for which LAW prescribes a maximum punishment of imprisonment for a term of DATE , life imprisonment or compulsory dissolution . A criminal offence in the second degree attracts imprisonment for a term DATE or a financial penalty .

According to LAW , which entered into force on DATE , an offence which is committed prior to entry into force of LAW and which is also punishable as a criminal offence pursuant to LAW shall be legally assessed pursuant to the corresponding section of LAW in force at the time of the commission of the offence . If , after entry into force of LAW , a punishment is imposed for a criminal offence committed prior to entry into force of LAW , the punishment shall be based on the punishment provided for in the corresponding section of LAW in force at the time of the commission of the offence , where the said section prescribes a lesser punishment .

The offence of unlawful handling of large quantities of narcotic drugs or psychotropic substances was punishable by CARDINAL to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment from DATE to DATE pursuant to LAW of GPE ( thus rendering the offence an offence in the second degree pursuant to LAW of GPE ) .
As from DATE the offence has been punishable by CARDINAL to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , thus rendering the offence an offence in the first degree ( pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW of GPE ) .

Conditional release ( release on parole ) is governed by section CARDINAL of LAW of GPE . According to subsection CARDINAL , if a person has been convicted of commission of a criminal offence in the second degree , or a criminal offence in the first degree through negligence , the court may release the convicted offender conditionally if he or she has actually served CARDINAL but not DATE of the term of the imposed punishment . Subsection CARDINAL provides that if a person has been convicted of intentional commission of a criminal offence in the first degree , the court may release the person conditionally if the convicted person has actually served CARDINAL of the term of the imposed punishment . Pursuant to subsection CARDINAL , in deciding on conditional release , the court shall take into consideration the circumstances relating to the commission of the criminal offence , the personality of the convicted offender , his or her previous personal history and conduct during the service of the sentence , his or her living conditions and the consequences which conditional release may bring about for the convicted offender .
